svcsubsecinfo.para: As in other systems, the regulator limits the system voltage by controlling the rotor field current. The regulator switches the field current on and off at a fixed frequency of about 400 cycles per second. By varying the on-off time, the correct average field current for proper system voltage control is obtained. At high speeds, the on-time may be 10%, and the off-time 90%. At low speeds with high electrical loads, the on-time and off-time may be 90% and 10% respectively.

The Packard type connector on the alternator ( ) has four terminals identified as "S," "I," "L" and "P." The use of the "P," "L," and "S" terminals is optional ( Figure 1). CS Series alternators require the "L" or "I" terminal wired to the chassis. The additional terminals allow other electrical devices to be connected to the alternator for a variety of purposes. The "S" terminal ( Figure 4) may be connected to an external voltage source, such as the battery, to sense the voltage being regulated. The "L" terminal supplies voltage for the field ( Figure 4). The "P" terminal is wired to the stator and may be used to drive a tachometer or other rpm sensing device ( Figure 4). The "I" terminal alone, or both the "I" and "L" terminals can supply voltage for the field ( Figure 4). The "I" terminal can be connected to the ignition switch either directly or through a resistance wire.
